title: 111_hr4914
content: The "Coastal Jobs Creation Act of 2010" aims to provide employment opportunities for coastal communities through support for cooperative research, infrastructure revitalization, recreational fishing programs, marine debris removal, and coastal resource restoration. The "Coastal Jobs Creation Act of 2010" establishes a Coastal Jobs Creation Grant Program using specific authorities listed in the Act to support coastal communities. The Coastal Jobs Creation Grant Program, established by the Coastal Jobs Creation Act of 2010, utilizes specific authorities to support coastal communities. Activities funded under the program include cooperative research on economic and social data related to fisheries management and identifying habitat areas. The Coastal Jobs Creation Grant Program supports coastal communities by funding activities such as cooperative research on fisheries management, habitat restoration, improving data accuracy, implementing fishing registry programs, training observers, preserving coastal resources, redeveloping waterfronts, and conducting research within estuarine areas. Research and monitoring in National Estuarine Research Reserve System, National Marine Sanctuary System, and coral reef ecosystems, local conservation strategies, innovations in coastal and ocean observation technologies, cooperative research for fishery and marine mammal stock assessments, bycatch reduction efforts, and marine debris prevention. The curr_chunk discusses funding criteria for projects related to marine debris, emphasizing employment opportunities, replicating successful projects, utilizing existing infrastructure, supporting research, and contributing to ecosystem restoration. Within 30 days of enactment, the Secretary will develop guidelines for the Coastal Jobs Creation Grant Program. SEC. 4 amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to include funding for States to establish a registry program. SEC. 5 authorizes $80,000,000 for the Coastal Jobs Creation Grant Program annually from 2011 to 2015, with a limit of 5% for administrative expenses.
